review.title: Supervised and Unsupervised Ensembling for Knowledge Base Population
review.abstract: We present results on combining supervised and unsupervised methods to ensemble multiple systems for two popular Knowledge Base Population (KBP) tasks, Cold Start Slot Filling (CSSF) and Tri-lingual Entity Discovery and Linking (TEDL). We demonstrate that our combined system along with auxiliary features outperforms the best performing system for both tasks in the 2015 competition, several ensembling baselines, as well as the state-of-the-art stacking approach to ensembling KBP systems. The success of our technique on two different and challenging problems demonstrates the power and generality of our combined approach to ensembling.

metadata.title: Supervised and Unsupervised Ensembling for Knowledge Base Population

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: In recent years, NIST has performed the English Slot Filling (ESF) and the Entity Discovery and Linking (EDL) tasks in the Knowledge Base Population (KBP) Track as part of the Text Analysis Conference (TAC). However, in 2015, the ESF task (Surdeanu, 2013; Surdeanu and Ji, 2014) was replaced by the Cold Start Slot Filling (CSSF) task, which requires filling specific information slots for a given set of query units based on a supplied text corpus. For the 2015 EDL task, two new foreign languages were introduced - Spanish and Chinese as well as English - and so the task was renamed Tri-lingual Entity Discovery and Linking (TEDL). (Ji et al., 2015) The goal was to discover entities for all three languages based on a supplied text corpus.

sections.heading: 3 Overview of KBP Tasks
sections.text: In this section, we give a brief overview of the individual tasks of the KBP that are covered in this paper.

sections.heading: 3.1 Cold Start Slot Filling
sections.text: The goal of the CSSF is to collect (fill in) information about specific attributes (slots) for a set of entities (queries) from a given corpus.The query units can be a person (PER), organization (ORG) or geopolitical entity (GPE).The slots are specified and the task for 2015 also included the reversal of each slot, for example the Slot Org: Subsidiaries and their reverse Org: Parents.Some slots (such as per: age) are rated individually, while others (such as per: children) have list values, i.e. they can accommodate multiple slot filers.The input for the CSSF is a set of queries and the corpus in which to search for information.The queries are provided in an XML format that contains an ID for the query, the name of the entity and the type of entity (PER, ORG or GPE).

sections.heading: 3.2 Tri-lingual Entity Discovery and Linking
sections.text: The goal of TEDL is to find all mentions in a corpus of English, Spanish, and Chinese documents, which can be a person (PER), an organization (ORG), a geopolitical entity (GPE), an entity (FAC), or a location (LOC). Entities types FAC and LOC were newly introduced in 2015, and the extracted mentions are then linked by their ID to an existing English KB entity. If there is no KB entry for an entity, systems are expected to group all mentions for that entity using a NIL ID. Input consists of a corpus of documents in the three languages and an English KB of entities, each with a name, ID, type, and multiple ratios that allow systems to identify unique entities.

sections.heading: 4 Algorithm
sections.text: This section describes our approach to combining both supervised and unsupervised methods. Figure 1 shows an overview of our system, which forms a definitive meta-classifier for combining multiple systems based on trust values and other auxiliary features depending on the task.

sections.heading: 4.1 Supervised Ensembling Approach
sections.text: We use the batch method for these common systems described in Viswanathan et al. (2015). The idea is to combine predictions by training a "meta-classifier" for weight and combining several models using their confidence values as characteristics. By training on a set of monitored data that differs from that used to form the individual models, it learns how to combine their results into an improved ensemble model. Output of the ensembling system is similar to the output of a single system, but productively aggregates the results from different systems. In a final step after processing, the results that are classified as "correct" by the classifier are retained, while the others are removed from the output. The meta-classifier makes a binary decision for each unique output that is presented as a key value pair. For the CSSF task, the key to assembling multiple systems is a query along with a slot type, for example, the lot we define for Obama.

sections.heading: 4.2 Unsupervised Ensembling Approach
sections.text: Only 38 of the 70 systems that participated in CSSF 2015 were also involved in 2014, and only 24 of the 34 systems that participated in TEDL 2015 also participated in the 2014 EDL task. Therefore, many KBP systems were new in 2015 and did not have any past training data required for the monitored approach. In fact, some of the new systems are better than the shared systems, for example, the hltcoe system did not participate in the use in 2014, but was also ranked fourth in the 2015 TEDL task (Ji et al., 2015). First, we have these unattended systems with the restricted optimization approach described by Wang et al. (2013) Their approach is specific to the English slot fill task and also relies somewhat on past data to identify certain parameter values. Below, we describe our modifications to their approach so that it can be applied to both KBP tasks in a purely unattended manner. The bottom half of the systems shows the systems without historical data similarity.

sections.heading: 4.3 Combining the Supervised and Unsupervised Approaches
sections.text: Our new approach combines these supervised and unsupervised approaches with a stacked meta-control as the last arbiter for the adoption of a particular key. Most KBP teams submit multiple variations of their system. Before executing the supervised and unsupervised approaches discussed above, we first combine several runs of the same team into one. Of the 38 CSSF systems, we tend to be smaller variations. For the slot fillings that exist between the runs of a particular team, we calculate the runs of each individual team into one to ensure the diversity of the ensemble.

sections.heading: 4.5 Post-processing
sections.text: Once we have received the decisions on each of the key value pairs from the stacker, we perform some final post-processing. To CSSF, this is simple: any list filling that is classified as correct is included in the final output. If monovalent slot fillings are multiple fillings that have been correctly classified for the same query and slot type, we include the filling with the highest meta-classifier trust. In TEDL, for each entity link that is classified as correct, the NIL IDs are resolved system-wide because NIL IDs are unique to each system. We merge NIL clusters system-wide into one when there is at least one common NIL cluster ID. Finally, we enter a new NIL ID for these newly merged clusters.

sections.heading: 5 Experimental Results
sections.text: This section describes a comprehensive set of experiments to evaluate ensemble for both KBP tasks using the algorithm described in the previous section, which compares our complete system with different ablations and previous results, all achieved using the official NIST scorers for the post-competition tasks. (2013) We compare our results with several fundamentals. We also compare our combined approach to Bipartite Graph based on consensus maximization (BGCM). (Gao et al., 2009) We use BGCM instead of the restricted optimization approach to maintain the rest of our pipeline. Second, we also compare the combination of both systems using BGCM instead of the restricted optimization approach to obtain.

sections.heading: 6 Related Work
sections.text: Although Viswanathan et al. (2015) applied stacking to filling KBP slots, we are expanding their approach to include new auxiliary features, combining supervised and unsupervised systems for both CSSF and TEDL. A fast and scalable method of collectively linking entities based on stacking was proposed by Viswanathan et al. (2013). They stack a global predictor on a local predictor to capture coherence information from adjacent decisions. Biomedical entity extraction using a stacked ensemble of an SVM and CRF proved to be better than single components and electoral foundations (Ekbal and Saha, 2013). Stacks for extracting information from an adjacent decision.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: This paper presented experimental results on two distinct KBP tasks, showing that a novel stack-based approach that resembles both monitored and unmonitored systems is very promising, delivering an overall score of 44.9% for the 2015 KBP CSSF task and a score of 65.3% for CEAFm F1 for the 2015 KBP TEDL, exceeding the first-place systems from both 2015 competitions and several other comparable methods, achieving a new state-of-the-art for these two important, challenging tasks. We found that the addition of the unattended ensemble, together with the shared systems, significantly increases recall and highlights the importance of using systems that do not have historical training data.As discussed in Section 5, two new auxiliary stacking functions for filling slots based on provenance similarity with the query document and document similarity between systems were improved.

sections.heading: 8 Acknowledgment
sections.text: This research was partially supported by the DARPA DEFT program under AFRL grant FA8750-13-20026 and the MURI ARO grant W911NF-08-10242.

referenceMentions.context: Using ensembles of multiple systems is a standard approach to improving accuracy in machine learning (Dietterich, 2000).

Ensembles have been applied to a wide variety of problems in natural language processing, including parsing (Henderson and Brill, 1999), word sense disambiguation (Pedersen, 2000), sentiment analysis (Whitehead and Yaeger, 2010) and information extraction (IE) (Florian et al.

Ensembles have been applied to a wide variety of problems in natural language processing, including parsing (Henderson and Brill, 1999), word sense disambiguation (Pedersen, 2000), sentiment analysis (Whitehead and Yaeger, 2010) and information extraction (IE) (Florian et al., 2003; McClosky et al., 2012).

Ensembles have been applied to a wide variety of problems in natural language processing, including parsing (Henderson and Brill, 1999), word sense disambiguation (Pedersen, 2000), sentiment analysis (Whitehead and Yaeger, 2010) and information extraction (IE) (Florian et al., 2003; McClosky et al., 2012).
Recently, using stacking (Wolpert, 1992) to ensemble IE systems was shown to give state-of-the-art results on slot-filling for Knowledge Base Population (KBP) (Viswanathan et al., 2015).

Using ensembles of multiple systems is a standard approach to improving accuracy in machine learning (Dietterich, 2000). Ensembles have been applied to a wide variety of problems in natural language processing, including parsing (Henderson and Brill, 1999), word sense disambiguation (Pedersen, 2000), sentiment analysis (Whitehead and Yaeger, 2010) and information extraction (IE) (Florian et al., 2003; McClosky et al., 2012). Recently, using stacking (Wolpert, 1992) to ensemble IE systems was shown to give state-of-the-art results on slot-filling for Knowledge Base Population (KBP) (Viswanathan et al., 2015). Stacking uses supervised learning to train a meta-classifier to combine multiple system outputs; therefore, it requires historical data on the performance of each system on a corpus of labeled training data. problems in NLP such as collective document classification (Kou and Cohen, 2007), named entity recognition (Florian, 2002), stacked dependency parsing (Martins et al., 2008) and joint Chinese word segmentation and part-of-speech tagging

(Sun, 2011). Although Viswanathan et al. (2015) applied stacking to KBP slot filling, we extend their approach with new auxiliary features and combine supervised and unsupervised systems for both CSSF and TEDL.
Stacking for information extraction has been demonstrated to outperform both majority voting and weighted voting methods (Sigletos et al., 2005).
The FAUST system for biomolecular even extraction uses model combination strategies such as voting and stacking and was placed first in three of the four BioNLP tasks in 2011 (Riedel et al., 2011).
Google’s Knowledge Vault system (Dong et al., 2014) combines four diverse extraction methods by building a boosted decision stump classifier (Reyzin and Schapire, 2006).

A fast and scalable collective entity linking method that relies on stacking was proposed by He et al. (2013). They stack a global predictor on top of a local predictor to collect coherence information from neighboring decisions.

metadata.abstractText: We present results on combining supervised and unsupervised methods to ensemble multiple systems for two popular Knowledge Base Population (KBP) tasks, Cold Start Slot Filling (CSSF) and Tri-lingual Entity Discovery and Linking (TEDL). We demonstrate that our combined system along with auxiliary features outperforms the best performing system for both tasks in the 2015 competition, several ensembling baselines, as well as the state-of-the-art stacking approach to ensembling KBP systems. The success of our technique on two different and challenging problems demonstrates the power and generality of our combined approach to ensembling.
